elements.title: Reference Point Comparison Engine at Search and Listing Evaluation
elements.problem: Guests arrive at Split Lease with a pre-existing reference point from their current alternative (Sonder at $90/night, Airbnb at variable prices, hotel at $170/night, or free but painful friend-couch arrangements). Kahneman's Prospect Theory demonstrates that all subsequent evaluations are coded as gains or losses relative to this reference point -- NOT as absolute values. Steve Zhang explicitly anchors on Sonder at $90/night in Boston. The current platform displays listing prices as nightly rates without any reference comparison. This forces the guest's System 2 to perform the translation ('Is $80/night better or worse than Sonder at $90/night? But wait, Sonder includes cleaning, and I don't need a kitchen...'), which is effortful, error-prone, and biased toward the vivid known alternative. Kahneman's bat-and-ball finding shows that even simple math is done wrong when an intuitive but incorrect answer is available. If a guest sees '$80/night' and their System 1 says 'that is close to Sonder and Sonder is certain,' the guest leaves. The platform has lost them to a cognitive illusion because the structural advantage (medium-term, no tourist tax, leave belongings, continuous space) was never surfaced against the reference point.
elements.solution: Build an explicit reference-point comparison into every listing display and the proposal creation flow. The system should: (1) During onboarding or first search, ask the guest what they currently pay for accommodation and what platform they use. This captures the reference point. (2) On every listing card and listing detail page, show a 'vs. your current option' comparison that calculates the monthly total for the guest's specific use pattern (e.g., 3 nights/week x 4 weeks = 12 nights x $80 = $960/month vs. Sonder at $90/night x 12 nights = $1,080/month -- you save $120/month PLUS you keep your stuff there). (3) Frame the comparison as a GAIN from the reference point, never as an absolute price. Kahneman shows that gain-framing is essential when the gain is moderate -- people are risk-averse in the gains domain and need to see the gain clearly to choose the uncertain option (Split Lease) over the certain one (Sonder). (4) Include the non-financial gains visually: 'Leave your laptop setup on the desk' with an icon, 'Same space every visit' with an icon, 'Full kitchen included' with an icon. These make the abstract advantage vivid, which Kahneman shows reduces the certainty premium the guest demands.

evidence.detail: Steve explicitly states his reference point: 'I also say to Sonder quite a bit... in Boston, I can get it down to like 90 a month.' This is not casual -- he has optimized his Sonder usage and knows his price point. Any Split Lease listing that does not beat $90/night on an apples-to-apples comparison will be dismissed by Steve's System 1 as 'more expensive than what I have.'

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Endowment Effect / Reference Points section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'The omission of the reference point from the indifference map is a surprising case of theory-induced blindness... If you changed jobs or locations, or even considered such a change, you surely remember that the features of the new place were coded as pluses or minuses relative to where you were.' Split Lease currently omits the reference point from its listing display, creating the same theory-induced blindness in its UI design.

Kahneman: 'A rich and vivid representation of the outcome... reduces the role of probability in the evaluation of an uncertain prospect.' The comparison engine must make Split Lease's advantages as vivid as the guest's known alternative. Abstract claims ('save up to 40%') are not vivid. Concrete comparisons ('You save $120/month and keep your laptop on the desk') are vivid.

Igor explains the resegmentation math to Steve in conversation: hotel parity pricing across cities, but monthly rental rates differ dramatically. Steve grasps this immediately because Igor presents it as a comparison, not an absolute. The platform must replicate this conversational comparison on-screen.

elements.user_goal: Instantly understand whether this listing is a better deal than my current alternative, without having to do any mental math or research.
elements.company_goal: Convert comparison-shoppers who would otherwise default to Sonder/Airbnb by making the structural price advantage visible at the moment of evaluation, reducing the certainty premium that favors known alternatives.
elements.time_budget: The reference-point comparison must be visible within 2 seconds of viewing a listing card or landing on a listing detail page. The guest should never have to scroll to find the comparison. On proposal creation, the comparison should be the first thing shown, before any form fields.
anti_goals: DO NOT show price as a standalone nightly rate without context. '$80/night' means nothing without 'vs. $90/night at Sonder for the same nights.'
DO NOT use abstract percentage savings ('Save up to 40%!'). Steve's System 2 will immediately ask '40% of what?' and his System 1 will distrust the vagueness.
DO NOT assume the guest's reference point. Ask for it (during onboarding or first search) and use it explicitly.

DO NOT hide the non-financial advantages (leave belongings, same space, full kitchen) in a features section far from the price. They ARE part of the price comparison because they reduce the guest's total cost of living.
elements.success_metric: Search-to-proposal conversion rate for guests who see reference-point comparisons vs. those who see standalone prices. Target: 2x improvement. Secondary: time-on-listing-page increase (indicating engagement rather than bouncing).

elements.title: Loss-State Acquisition Funnel for Housing-Unstable Guests
elements.problem: Kahneman's fourfold pattern shows that people currently experiencing losses are risk-seeking -- they are willing to try novel, uncertain options that loss-averse people would reject. Steve Zhang is a textbook loss-state guest: no permanent lease, storing belongings with friends, house-sitting, living out of a suitcase at his girlfriend's place. He explicitly describes his situation as 'very inefficient.' This loss-state creates a time-limited acquisition window: Steve is more receptive to trying Split Lease NOW than he will be once he settles into any stable arrangement (even a suboptimal one like a Sonder monthly). Once he establishes a new status quo, the endowment effect and status quo bias will lock him into that arrangement and make him resistant to switching. The current platform treats all guests identically -- the same search flow, the same listing pages, the same proposal process. It does not recognize or capitalize on the loss-state window. A guest who is housing-unstable and browsing at 11pm on a Tuesday is treated the same as a guest casually exploring options from a comfortable apartment.
elements.solution: Create a differentiated acquisition path for loss-state guests that compresses the time from discovery to proposal. This means: (1) In the discovery/onboarding flow, ask a qualification question: 'What's your current housing situation?' with options like 'I have a stable lease,' 'I'm between places,' 'I'm using hotels/Sonder,' 'I'm staying with friends/family.' Guests who select loss-state options enter an accelerated funnel. (2) The accelerated funnel front-loads certainty: immediately show available listings in the guest's target area with move-in dates within the next 2 weeks, total monthly costs (not nightly rates), and one-click proposal creation with smart defaults. (3) Reduce the number of decisions required. Loss-state guests are already making decisions under stress -- Kahneman shows that people 'in the losses' process options differently, focusing on loss-reduction rather than gain-maximization. The funnel should emphasize what they STOP losing (no more suitcase, no more imposing on friends, no more setup/teardown) rather than what they gain. (4) Create urgency through honest scarcity signals: 'This space is available starting Feb 20. 2 other guests are evaluating it.' Loss-state guests are risk-seeking; legitimate urgency aligns with their psychological state.

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Many unfortunate human situations unfold in the top right cell. This is where people who face very bad options take desperate gambles, accepting a high probability of making things worse in exchange for a small hope of avoiding a large loss.' Steve is in this quadrant for housing: his current situation is a continuous loss, making him willing to try the 'gamble' of a novel platform.

Kahneman: 'People who are poor think like traders... all their choices are between losses. Money that is spent on one good is the loss of another good.' Steve is housing-poor: every housing dollar he spends (Sonder, hotels) is a loss of money that could go elsewhere. He is primed to find the option that minimizes total losses.

Steve describes his loss state in vivid detail: consolidated belongings to friends' homes, working from Airtable (remote), house-sitting in Boston, living out of a suitcase at girlfriend's house, girlfriend has 'a smaller place' and 'a husband,' he doesn't want to 'stay in there for like a month.' Every detail is a loss. He is the ideal loss-state acquisition target.

Steve: 'Every time you have to set it up, your ROI is like a couple of days.' He is thinking in ROI terms about his housing transitions. A loss-state funnel that shows the ROI of a stable Split Lease arrangement (vs. the ongoing loss of temporary arrangements) speaks directly to his mental model.

elements.user_goal: Find a stable living arrangement as quickly as possible, with minimal decision-making overhead, at a cost that stops my current financial bleeding.
elements.company_goal: Capture loss-state guests during their time-limited acquisition window before they settle into a suboptimal but sticky alternative (Sonder, extended-stay hotel, renewed friend-couch arrangement), which would then be protected by endowment effect and status quo bias.
elements.time_budget: Loss-state guests should be able to go from first landing to submitted proposal in under 10 minutes. Every additional minute increases the risk that they solve their immediate problem through another channel (texting a friend, booking Sonder) and exit the loss-state window.
anti_goals: DO NOT make loss-state guests go through the same leisurely browsing flow as stable-housing guests. Their psychology is different and their time horizon is shorter.
DO NOT emphasize luxury or lifestyle benefits to loss-state guests. They are not shopping for lifestyle -- they are trying to stop losing. Frame everything as loss-reduction.

DO NOT create artificial urgency or false scarcity. Loss-state guests are already anxious; dishonest urgency will trigger the rare-events overweighting and make them think the platform is manipulative.
DO NOT require extensive profile completion before showing listings. Loss-state guests want to see what's available NOW, not fill out a profile for future matches.
elements.success_metric: Time-to-first-proposal for loss-state guests vs. stable-housing guests. Target: loss-state guests submit proposals 50% faster. Secondary: loss-state guest conversion rate (proposal to acceptance) should exceed 30%.

elements.title: Certainty Delivery System at Every Commitment Escalation
elements.problem: Kahneman's certainty effect demonstrates that moving from 95% to 100% certainty has disproportionate psychological impact -- far greater than any other 5% probability change. At every commitment escalation point in the guest journey (submitting a proposal, receiving a counter-offer, accepting terms, preparing to move in), the guest faces uncertainty about what happens next. Steve Zhang's background reveals why this matters especially for analytical guests: he understands uncertainty quantitatively (schedule certainty vs. uncertainty discussion at 0:17:25), he has experienced the pain of uncertainty (digital nomadism, no permanent lease, unclear work-from-office requirements at 0:06:27), and he will not commit resources to an uncertain outcome when a certain alternative exists (Sonder). The current platform's proposal flow introduces multiple points of uncertainty: Will the host respond? How long will it take? What if they counter? What exactly is the cancellation policy? What happens to my payment if the host cancels? Each uncertainty is a 'probability less than 100%' that triggers the certainty effect -- the guest overweights the small chance of a bad outcome and underweights the high chance of a good one.
elements.solution: At every commitment escalation point, deliver explicit certainty about what happens next, when it happens, and what the guest can do if it does not happen. This means: (1) Proposal submission: immediately show 'Your proposal has been sent. Hosts typically respond within [X] hours. If the host does not respond within 48 hours, your proposal expires and you are charged nothing.' The 'charged nothing' is the certainty guarantee that eliminates the loss-aversion trigger. (2) Counter-offer receipt: show exactly what changed, what did NOT change, and the total financial impact. Frame changes in gain terms: 'The host proposed 10 weeks instead of 16. This reduces your total commitment by $X while keeping your nightly rate the same.' (3) Acceptance: deliver a comprehensive 'What Happens Now' timeline -- documents in X hours, payment processed on Y date, move-in instructions sent Z days before. The timeline converts the probabilistic future into a certain sequence. (4) Pre-move-in: send the House Manual, check-in instructions, host contact info, and a 'What to bring' checklist 72 hours before. The guest should arrive with zero unresolved questions. Kahneman shows that the certainty premium people pay (in the insurance and settlement examples) can be captured by the platform as conversion rate improvement -- guests who receive certainty convert at dramatically higher rates because they do not need to pay the certainty premium by choosing the safe alternative (Sonder).

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'The improvement from 95% to 100% is another qualitative change that has a large impact, the certainty effect... a large industry of structured settlements exists to provide certainty at a hefty price, by taking advantage of the certainty effect.' Split Lease can provide certainty at no price premium, converting guests who would otherwise pay the Sonder certainty premium.

Kahneman: 'Overweighting of small probabilities increases the attractiveness of both gambles and insurance policies.' When a guest considers a Split Lease proposal, they are overweighting the small probability of a bad outcome (host cancels, space does not match photos). The certainty delivery system functions as free insurance that eliminates the overweighted risk.

Igor explicitly names the psychological dynamic: 'One of the things that multi locals have is schedule uncertainty. They have a sense of schedule certainty in a sense of schedule uncertainty. Like things could change or they want to tack on nights where they want their space back.' The platform must convert uncertainty to certainty at every step.

Steve: 'I came back because I thought I have to go back to January, but that's not going to happen. And I should've never, ever been at the office always again.' Steve has been burned by uncertainty (expected to return to office, then did not). He is sensitized to uncertain commitments and will demand certainty from the platform.

elements.user_goal: Know exactly what will happen, when it will happen, and what I can do about it at every step of the process. Never feel like I am waiting in the dark for someone else's decision.
elements.company_goal: Reduce the certainty premium that drives guests to known alternatives (Sonder, hotels) by making the Split Lease commitment process as certain as booking a Sonder room, while preserving the marketplace flexibility that creates the price advantage.
elements.time_budget: Certainty information must be delivered within 1 second of each commitment action. The 'What Happens Next' display should be immediate, not sent via email hours later. The guest's System 1 must register certainty before their System 2 starts calculating risks.
anti_goals: DO NOT promise certainty you cannot deliver. If average host response time is 18 hours, say '18 hours' not '24 hours.' Under-promise and over-deliver on certainty timelines.
DO NOT bury certainty information in terms of service, FAQ pages, or help docs. It must be in the primary flow, at the moment of decision.

DO NOT conflate certainty about the process with certainty about the outcome. The guest cannot be certain the host will accept their proposal, but they CAN be certain about what happens if the host does not accept.

DO NOT let the guest's imagination fill in the gaps. Kahneman shows that ambiguity is resolved by System 1 in threat-detection mode. If the platform does not specify what happens when X goes wrong, the guest's System 1 will imagine the worst case.
elements.success_metric: Proposal submission rate among guests who reach the proposal creation page. Target: 60% (currently estimated below 30% due to commitment anxiety). Secondary: guest-reported 'confidence in the process' score above 4/5.

elements.title: Endowment Effect Acceleration Through Pre-Acceptance Mental Ownership
elements.problem: Kahneman's endowment effect research shows that people value things they own approximately 2x more than identical things they do not own. Critically, this effect begins with mental ownership, not just physical possession. A guest who has imagined themselves in a space, configured their ideal dates, and calculated their monthly cost has begun to 'own' the outcome -- even before submitting a proposal. The current platform does not deliberately accelerate this mental ownership. Listing pages show photos and prices but do not help the guest project themselves into the space. The proposal form collects terms but does not reinforce the imagined future. This is a missed opportunity: if the platform can accelerate mental ownership before the commitment point (proposal submission), the endowment effect will make the guest reluctant to abandon the process. Not submitting the proposal will feel like a loss (losing the space they already mentally inhabit), rather than a neutral non-action. Steve Zhang is particularly susceptible to this because he is currently housing-unstable -- his desire for a space is acute, and any listing that matches his needs will trigger intense mental ownership because it represents relief from his loss state.
elements.solution: Design the listing evaluation and proposal creation flow to deliberately accelerate mental ownership through personalization and projection. This means: (1) On the listing detail page, after the guest has viewed photos and price, offer a 'Plan Your Stay' interactive section that asks for their target dates and shows a calendar with their specific nights highlighted. The moment they see THEIR dates on the calendar, they have mentally moved in. (2) Show a personalized cost summary that uses the guest's name: 'Steve, your 3-night/week stay in Cambridge would cost $960/month -- $120 less than Sonder.' The personalization triggers ownership because it is no longer a generic listing; it is Steve's arrangement. (3) During proposal creation, show a 'Your Space' summary card that includes the listing photo, the guest's configured dates, and the total cost -- all presented as if the arrangement already exists. This is the 'mug in front of you' from Kahneman's experiment: the Sellers who had the mug in front of them valued it 2x more. (4) If the host counters, frame the counter not as a change to 'the listing' but as a change to 'your arrangement.' The endowment effect now works for the platform: the guest is reluctant to lose 'their arrangement' and is more likely to accept a reasonable counter.

evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'The average selling price was about double the average buying price, and the estimated number of trades was less than half of the number predicted by standard theory.' This is the raw power of the endowment effect. A guest who mentally 'owns' a listing will require roughly 2x the inducement to abandon it. The platform can harness this by making mental ownership happen early.

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Endowment Effect section (Sellers vs Choosers)
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'The gap between Sellers and Choosers is remarkable... The only difference is in the emotion of the moment.' Sellers (who had the mug) valued it at $7.12. Choosers (who could get the mug or cash) valued it at $3.12. The ONLY difference was possession. On the listing page, the guest is a Chooser (browsing options). After configuring dates and seeing 'Your Space,' the guest becomes a Seller (protecting their arrangement).

Steve: 'For that six months I missed the house. Like I have to have them here.' Steve has a demonstrated capacity for intense place-attachment. The endowment effect for a living space will be especially strong for him because he has experienced place-loss and knows the pain.

Steve: 'I basically work at Airtable. So I have like, basically my belongings friends who are...' His belongings are dispersed. The mental image of his belongings in ONE place (a Split Lease space) will trigger intense mental ownership because it represents the reunification of his scattered life.

elements.user_goal: Feel like this space is already mine by the time I submit the proposal, so that submitting is just formalizing what I already know I want.
elements.company_goal: Use the endowment effect to increase proposal submission rates by making non-submission feel like a loss rather than a neutral non-action, and to increase counter-offer acceptance rates by making the arrangement feel like the guest's property.
elements.time_budget: Mental ownership should begin within 60 seconds of landing on a listing detail page. The 'Plan Your Stay' interaction should take under 30 seconds. The total time from listing arrival to mental ownership should be under 90 seconds.
anti_goals: DO NOT create false ownership that will be betrayed. If the listing is actually unavailable for the guest's dates, do not let them configure a stay and then show an error. This is the worst possible outcome: the guest loses something they thought they owned.
DO NOT make the 'Plan Your Stay' interaction mandatory. Some guests want to browse casually. The tool should be available and inviting, not required.
DO NOT personalize so aggressively that it feels like surveillance. 'Steve, we noticed you looked at this listing 3 times' is creepy. 'Steve, your estimated monthly cost' is helpful.

DO NOT rely on mental ownership to compensate for a bad product. If the listing is overpriced or the photos are misleading, accelerating mental ownership will increase the anger of discovery, not the rate of conversion.
elements.success_metric: Proposal submission rate for guests who use 'Plan Your Stay' vs. those who do not. Target: 3x improvement. Secondary: counter-offer acceptance rate for guests who see 'Your Space' framing vs. neutral framing. Target: 40% improvement.

elements.title: Loss-Framed Retention System During Active Lease
elements.problem: During the active lease phase, the guest has established a new reference point: 'I have a stable space.' The endowment effect and status quo bias now work for retention -- but only if the platform does not actively undermine them. Kahneman's research shows two risks: (1) Negative experiences are coded as losses and weighted 2:1 against positive experiences. One bad interaction (payment confusion, unresponsive host, difficult date change) creates a loss that requires two positive experiences to offset. (2) The guest's reference point rises over time -- they begin to expect not just the space but the entire support system (responsive host, flexible dates, transparent payments). Any failure to meet the rising expectation is a loss. Steve Zhang's situation is especially important here because he is analytical and will track his ROI continuously. If the monthly cost creeps up, if date changes become difficult, if the host becomes less responsive, Steve will code these as losses from his established reference and begin evaluating alternatives. The platform currently has no system for monitoring guest reference points or proactively preventing loss events.
elements.solution: Build a loss-prevention system into the active lease experience. This means: (1) Proactive payment transparency: show the guest their running total, their savings vs. the reference alternative (Sonder/hotel), and any upcoming charges BEFORE they occur. No surprise charges ever. Kahneman: 'Unfairly imposing losses on people can be risky if the victims are in a position to retaliate.' Payment surprises are perceived as unfair losses. (2) Host responsiveness monitoring: if the host's response time to messages or date-change requests degrades, the platform should intervene proactively (nudge the host, offer the guest a direct support contact). (3) Date Change Tool framing: when a date change is processed, frame the result in terms of what was PRESERVED, not what changed. 'Your 3-night Tuesday-Thursday arrangement continues. Wednesday has been swapped to Thursday for Week 7.' The unchanged elements should be visually dominant. (4) Lease renewal framing: as the lease end approaches, frame non-renewal as a loss: 'Your space in Cambridge ends on [date]. Renewing preserves your $960/month rate and your setup.' The endowment effect makes this framing honest, not manipulative -- the guest genuinely will lose something they value. (5) Mid-lease check-in: at the halfway point, show the guest a 'Your Stay So Far' summary: nights stayed, total saved vs. alternatives, host rating. This is the digital equivalent of Kahneman's finding that seeing your portfolio gains reinforces the endowment effect.

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Bad Events / Negativity Dominance section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Bad emotions, bad parents, and bad feedback have more impact than good ones... Gottman estimated that a stable relationship requires that good interactions outnumber bad interactions by at least 5 to 1.' The guest-host relationship during active lease follows the same dynamic. The platform must prevent bad interactions, not just create good ones.

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Loss Aversion in the Law / Fairness section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Employers who violate rules of fairness are punished by reduced productivity, and merchants who follow unfair pricing policies can expect to lose sales.' Payment surprises and hidden fees violate the guest's fairness expectations and trigger retaliatory behavior (negative reviews, non-renewal, chargeback disputes).

Steve on Sonder: 'Their text conversations are, if you don't respond within like 30 seconds, you're like, who does this? Like at my Amex later and they keep going. It's super annoying.' Steve is acutely sensitive to operational friction during active use. He will apply the same scrutiny to Split Lease. Any friction is a loss from his expectation.

Steve on the value proposition: 'A much more sustainable living arrangement, in terms both price and quality.' 'Sustainable' is the reference expectation. Any interruption to sustainability (payment surprise, date-change friction, host unresponsiveness) is a loss from this promise.

elements.user_goal: Never be surprised by a cost, a rule change, or a process failure during my lease. Feel continuously informed about the value I am receiving.
elements.company_goal: Maximize lease renewal rates by preventing the loss events that erode the endowment effect, and by framing renewal as loss-prevention (preserving what the guest has) rather than gain-seeking (getting something new).
elements.time_budget: Payment notifications should arrive 72 hours before any charge. Host responsiveness alerts should trigger within 24 hours of degradation. Date change confirmations should be immediate. Lease renewal prompts should begin 4 weeks before lease end.
anti_goals: DO NOT wait for the guest to discover a problem. By the time they find a payment error or a date-change rejection, the loss has already been coded and the damage to retention is done.

DO NOT frame lease renewal as a new decision. It should feel like maintaining the status quo, which Kahneman shows is the psychologically preferred option. 'Continue your stay' is better than 'Book a new lease.'
DO NOT send excessive check-ins or notifications that create notification fatigue. Each notification must carry certainty-enhancing information, not just engagement bait.

DO NOT rely on the endowment effect alone for retention. If the product is genuinely worse than alternatives, the endowment effect delays churn but does not prevent it. The loss-prevention system must address real problems, not just perceptions.
elements.success_metric: Lease renewal rate for guests who experience zero loss events vs. those who experience one or more. Target: 80% renewal for zero-loss guests, with each loss event reducing renewal probability by 15-20%. Secondary: guest-reported satisfaction maintained above 4.2/5 throughout the lease.

elements.title: Negotiation Reframing Engine to Neutralize Counter-Offer Loss Aversion
elements.problem: Kahneman's research on negotiation shows that 'loss aversion creates an asymmetry that makes agreements difficult to reach. The concessions you make to me are my gains, but they are your losses; they cause you much more pain than they give me pleasure.' In Split Lease negotiation, when a host counters a guest's proposal (e.g., reducing duration from 16 to 10 weeks), the guest's System 1 immediately codes every change as a loss from their proposed terms. The guest's proposal has become their reference point -- not the pre-proposal state of having no space at all. This is the endowment effect applied to proposal terms: the guest 'owns' their proposed dates and duration. The current platform shows counter-offers as changes to the proposal, which highlights what was lost. This framing maximizes loss aversion and minimizes the probability of acceptance. The result: negotiation rounds increase, time-to-agreement extends, and guests who would have accepted reasonable counters abandon because the loss signal is too strong.
elements.solution: Redesign the counter-offer display to neutralize loss aversion through deliberate framing. This means: (1) Lead with what was PRESERVED: 'The host agreed to your nightly rate of $80 and your preferred move-in date.' These are gains from the pre-proposal state (having nothing). (2) Present changes as the host's contribution, not the guest's concession: 'The host is offering 10 weeks instead of 16 -- this reduces your total commitment from $3,840 to $2,400.' Frame the change as a smaller commitment, not a shorter stay. (3) Show the 'negotiation distance' visually: a bar showing original proposal, counter-offer, and how close they are to agreement. Kahneman's research on negotiating a shrinking vs. expanding pie applies: if the guest perceives the negotiation as 'allocating gains' (moving toward having a space), they will be more flexible. If they perceive it as 'allocating losses' (losing proposed terms), they will be rigid. (4) Provide a one-click 'Accept counter' with a gain-framed summary: 'Accept and secure your space in Cambridge starting [date].' The word 'secure' activates the certainty effect -- accepting converts an uncertain negotiation into a certain outcome. (5) If the guest wants to counter-counter, provide smart suggestions that are calibrated to the midpoint, making the guest feel they are gaining ground rather than defending territory.

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Defending the Status Quo section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Loss aversion creates an asymmetry that makes agreements difficult to reach... Negotiations over a shrinking pie are especially difficult, because they require an allocation of losses. People tend to be much more easygoing when they bargain over an expanding pie.' The counter-offer display must present the negotiation as an expanding pie (both parties moving toward an agreement) not a shrinking one (guest losing proposed terms).

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Endowment Effect / Albert and Ben section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'Albert will stay at A because the disadvantage of moving outweighs the advantage.' Once Steve has proposed 16 weeks, moving to 10 weeks is coded as a 6-week loss, even though 10 weeks of a stable space is vastly better than 0 weeks (his current situation). The framing must reset the comparison to the pre-proposal state, not the proposal state.

Igor discusses schedule certainty and uncertainty. In negotiation, each counter-offer re-introduces uncertainty. The reframing engine must minimize the uncertainty signal by emphasizing what is certain (agreed terms) and contextualizing what is uncertain (terms still in negotiation).

evidence.source: kahneman-part4, Fourfold Pattern / Gambling in the Shadow of the Law section
evidence.detail: Kahneman: 'A defendant with a weak case is likely to be risk seeking, prepared to gamble rather than accept a very unfavorable settlement.' If the counter-offer feels like a large loss, the guest may risk-seekingly reject it and walk away (the 'gamble' of finding something better), even when accepting would be the rational choice. The reframing engine prevents this by making the counter feel like a small concession, not a large loss.

elements.user_goal: Understand whether the host's counter-offer is reasonable, see exactly what changed and what did not, and feel like the negotiation is moving toward agreement rather than away from my ideal outcome.
elements.company_goal: Increase counter-offer acceptance rate by reframing changes as reduced commitments or preserved agreements rather than losses from proposed terms, reducing negotiation rounds and time-to-agreement.
elements.time_budget: Counter-offer display should load in under 2 seconds with the preserved-terms-first framing immediately visible. The guest should be able to accept or counter within 30 seconds of viewing.
anti_goals: DO NOT show changes in red or with negative visual signals (strikethrough, minus signs). Red triggers System 1 threat detection. Use neutral or positive visual signals for changes.
DO NOT display the counter-offer as a diff against the original proposal. Diffs emphasize losses. Show the counter as a complete, self-contained offer with preserved elements highlighted.
DO NOT allow the negotiation to feel adversarial. The platform is a mediator, not a battleground. Language should be collaborative: 'The host suggests...' not 'The host has changed...'
DO NOT hide the option to counter-counter. Some guests need to feel in control. But make acceptance the visually prominent, easy path.
elements.success_metric: Counter-offer acceptance rate on first counter. Target: above 50%. Secondary: average negotiation rounds per successful agreement should be below 2.0.
